facts: Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 29,032 feet (8,848 meters) above sea level.
Mount Everest is located in the Himalayas on the border between Nepal and China.
Mount Everest was first successfully summited by Sir Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa of Nepal, on May 29, 1953.
K2, also known as Mount Godwin-Austen, is the second-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 28,251 feet (8,611 meters) above sea level.
K2 is located in the Karakoram Range on the China-Pakistan border.
K2 is considered one of the most difficult mountains to climb, with a high fatality rate among climbers.
Kangchenjunga is the third-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 28,169 feet (8,586 meters) above sea level.
Kangchenjunga is located in the Himalayas on the India-Nepal border.
Kangchenjunga is considered sacred by the local people, and climbing to the summit is prohibited.
Lhotse is the fourth-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 27,940 feet (8,516 meters) above sea level.
Lhotse is located in the Himalayas on the border between Nepal and China, near Mount Everest.
Lhotse is connected to Mount Everest by the South Col, making it a popular destination for climbers attempting to summit both peaks.
Makalu is the fifth-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 27,838 feet (8,485 meters) above sea level.
Makalu is located in the Himalayas on the border between Nepal and China.

Cho Oyu is the sixth-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 26,906 feet (8,201 meters) above sea level.
Cho Oyu is located in the Himalayas on the China-Nepal border.
Cho Oyu is considered one of the easiest 8,000-meter peaks to climb, making it popular among mountaineers.
Dhaulagiri is the seventh-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 26,795 feet (8,167 meters) above sea level.
Dhaulagiri is located in the Himalayas of Nepal.
Dhaulagiri was first climbed in 1960 by a Swiss-Austrian expedition led by Max Eiselin.
Manaslu is the eighth-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 26,781 feet (8,163 meters) above sea level.

Nanga Parbat is the ninth-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 26,660 feet (8,126 meters) above sea level.
Nanga Parbat is located in the Himalayas of Pakistan.
Nanga Parbat is nicknamed the 'Killer Mountain' due to its high fatality rate among climbers.
Annapurna is the tenth-highest mountain in the world, with a peak reaching 26,545 feet (8,091 meters) above sea level.
Annapurna is located in the Himalayas of Nepal.
Annapurna was the first 8,000-meter peak to be climbed, achieved by a French expedition led by Maurice Herzog in 1950.
